awd_titl_txt: Protein Regulators of 3D Genome Architecture: Dynamics, Mechanism and Function
awd_abstract_narration:
The research project will contribute to our understanding of 3D genome folding. Proper regulation of gene expression is essential in all biological organisms. In mammals, most genes are regulated by distal enhancers that can be located far away from their target genes on the linear genome. Perhaps for this reason, mammalian genomes are folded into 3D domains that ensure enhancers interact with the appropriate genes through space. This research will provide key insights into an understudied potential regulator of 3D genome domains. The project will create interdisciplinary training opportunities for a graduate student and a post-doctoral associate, supporting their development as scientists in academia, biomedical industry and/or related careers. Additional broader impact will be achieved through integration of the imaging aspects of the project with an undergraduate course at MIT (20.309), summer research opportunities for undergraduates from underrepresented groups in STEM disciplines and through outreach activities.  

CTCF is the best-known insulator between enhancers and promoters in mammalian cells. CTCF, together with the cohesin complex, fold the genome into chromatin loops and loop domains. However, not all loops have CTCF at their anchors, and since CTCF is expressed in all cell types, it is currently difficult to explain why loops differ between cell types. Moreover, several studies have provided evidence that other DNA-binding proteins are strongly enriched at loop anchors. The research will study such a candidate looping factor, ZNF143, in detail. Acute depletion followed by Micro-C will reveal its role in 3D genome organization and looping. Live-cell and super-resolution microscopy will reveal its dynamics, target-search mechanism, residence time, and provide quantitative constraints on 3D genome models. Taken together, the research will expand knowledge of critical genome organizing factors beyond CTCF.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the NSF project #2036037 entitled Protein Regulators of 3D Genome Architecture: Dynamics, Mechanism and Function, we sought to better understand how a specific protein, ZNF143, might regulate 3D genome architecture.

 

Regulation of 3D genome architecture is important for the regulation of gene expression, DNA repair, and several other key processes. Two protein factors, CTCF and cohesin, are well-known to regulate 3D genome architecture by folding the genome into loops and domains, but they cannot explain the formation of all loops and domains. The most strongly implicated other protein factor in regulating loop formation is the protein ZNF143, which is why we studied it in this project. To our great surprise and contrary to a number of published papers, we found that ZNF143 plays no role in loop formation (Narducci & Hansen, BioRxiv 2024; findings independently confirmed by Magnitov et al., BioRxiv 2024). ZNF143 was erroneously implicated as a looping factor due to a variety of reasons, but starting with a ZNF143 antibody that cross-reacts with CTCF. Our results clearly establish that ZNF143 has no role in loop formation but that it is instead a highly conserved transcriptional regulator that regulates ribosomal and mitochondrial genes and which is essential.

 

These results, together with other recently reported results in the literature, suggest that there may only be two strong loop-forming factors, CTCF and cohesin, and that going forward, we may need to think of other mechanisms when thinking about how non-CTCF/cohesin loops are formed. In particular, we suggest that the loops that form between enhancers and genes to regulate gene expression may be mediated by the aggregate weak interactions of all the transcriptional proteins bound rather than by the action of single looping factor proteins.

 

Additionally, this project enabled interdisciplinary training opportunities for graduate students and undergraduate students. The project provided research opportunities for summer undergraduate students through the MIT Summer Research Program as well as for two MIT undergraduates. The broader impacts of the project were disseminated to the public and are currently under peer review and will be published in due time.
